title: How to Add a Pop of Color to Wooden Items

parts.name: Selecting and Preparing the Wooden Items

steps.headline: Choose your wooden items.
steps.description: This could include a set such as a bowl, large spoon and plate or it could be a piece of furniture.

steps.headline: Make sure the wooden item is pre-sanded.
steps.description: This will ensure that each item is ready to accept paint.

steps.headline: Clean or remove debris from wooden item.
steps.description: Run a clean cloth over the wooden item; use a slightly dampened cloth to avoid soaking the wooden piece. Use light sandpaper to buff out any rough areas of necessary and then smooth over with your cloth.

steps.headline: Come up with your design for each wooden piece.
steps.description: For smaller items, keep the design simple. Seek for just a pop of color rather than overwhelming it. If doing a set, you might like to carry the pattern across each piece, to keep it in theme.

steps.headline: Tape off your design.
steps.description:
Use the tape to block off your color design. Keep in mind you will be painting within the tape barriers, so precision is key. steps.headline: Paint your design.
steps.description:

steps.headline: Consider painting two coats for completeness of coverage.
steps.description: Always allow proper drying times in between coats.

steps.headline: Add clear coat or glaze to seal the completely dried piece.
steps.description: Add at least one coat, possibly two coats of glaze.

text:
Selecting and Preparing the Wooden Items Choose your wooden items. This could include a set such as a bowl, large spoon and plate or it could be a piece of furniture. Make sure the wooden item is pre-sanded. This will ensure that each item is ready to accept paint. Clean or remove debris from wooden item. Run a clean cloth over the wooden item; use a slightly dampened cloth to avoid soaking the wooden piece. Use light sandpaper to buff out any rough areas of necessary and then smooth over with your cloth. Adding the Design Come up with your design for each wooden piece. For smaller items, keep the design simple. Seek for just a pop of color rather than overwhelming it. If doing a set, you might like to carry the pattern across each piece, to keep it in theme. Tape off your design. Use the tape to block off your color design. Keep in mind you will be painting within the tape barriers, so precision is key.
